article: There's a new guy in the office. I don't know his name, but he seems nice enough. He's pleasant and _ a lot. When we walk by each other in the hallway we smile and say hi, Actually, he says, "Hi, Joe." I just say "Hi," _ ,well, I don't know his name, and I'm _ to ask. I mean, he's been here for a couple weeks. I _ know his name. But I don't. Last week I _ one of his colleagues talking to him. I listened for a minute to see if his _ was mentioned. The new guy mentioned the other person's name a couple of times, but the other person _ called the new guy _ name. I passed him in the hall again yesterday. He said "Hi, Joe." And I said "Hey, how's it going?" And I moved on down the hall feeling _ about how well I was coping with not knowing his name, when I heard a _ voice behind me. "I don't know you!" It was Sylvia, one of the kindest, most _ people I know. She has been walking a few paces behind me, and _ she didn't know the new guy either. But rather than just smile and say "hi", Sylvia did _ Sylvia does. Not only did she _ that she didn't know him, but she also asked him his name, told him her name and _ him in conversation. And suddenly for Sylvia, the new guy wasn't the new guy and more. He was Mitch, a colleague with children, hobbies, interests and a little shared history. I was _ by the ease with which Sylvia had made that change. It turns out it doesn't _ much to turn an unfamiliar face in the hall into a _ . You just have to get over yourself and reach out a little. Ask a question. Learn a name. And just like that - no more new guys.
